title: 3.1: Basic Forces and Physics
summary: Learn to apply forces like gravity to particles using UpdateDirectionBlock
intro: In this lesson, you'll learn how to apply forces to particles, such as gravity. We'll use UpdateDirectionBlock to modify particle direction over time, and combine it with delta time to create realistic physics-based movement.
steps: Create a SystemBlock - this is the root of your particle system
Create a CreateParticleBlock to emit particles
Set an initial color and size using ParticleInputBlock
Add a <filter-value>SphereShape</filter-value> block to emit particles from a sphere volume
Add an UpdateDirectionBlock to modify particle direction
Get the current direction using ParticleInputBlock with Direction contextual value
Get delta time using ParticleInputBlock with Delta system source
Create a gravity vector using ParticleConverterBlock (0, -9.8, 0 for downward gravity)
Multiply gravity by delta time to get gravity acceleration per frame
Add the gravity delta to the current direction using ParticleMathBlock
Connect the result to UpdateDirectionBlock's direction input

blocks.name: UpdateDirectionBlock
blocks.description: Updates the direction of particles each frame. This is essential for applying forces like gravity, wind, or other directional effects.

properties.name: name
properties.description: The display name of the block

properties.name: direction
properties.description: The new direction vector to apply to the particle. Can be calculated from current direction plus forces.

blocks.name: ParticleInputBlock (Direction)
blocks.description: Retrieves the current direction of a particle. Direction represents the velocity vector of the particle.

properties.name: contextualValue
properties.description: The type of contextual data - Direction in this case

blocks.name: ParticleInputBlock (Delta Time)
blocks.description: Retrieves the delta time from the system. Delta time is the time elapsed since the last frame, essential for frame-rate independent physics calculations.

properties.name: systemSource
properties.description: The system source - Delta for delta time

blocks.name: ParticleConverterBlock
blocks.description: Creates Vector3 from individual X, Y, Z float values. Used to construct the gravity vector (0, -9.8, 0).

properties.name: xIn, yIn, zIn
properties.description: Individual float inputs for X, Y, Z components

blocks.name: ParticleMathBlock (Multiply)
blocks.description: Multiplies two values. Used to multiply gravity by delta time, ensuring physics calculations are frame-rate independent.

blocks.name: ParticleMathBlock (Add)
blocks.description: Adds two Vector3 values. Used to add gravity acceleration to the current direction vector.

blocks.name: Sphere Shape Block
blocks.description: Emits particles from a sphere volume. Used in this lesson to create particles that fall due to gravity. In the visual editor, you can find this block in the block list and configure its properties in the properties panel on the right.

properties.name: Name
properties.description: The display name of the emitter. Set this in the properties panel on the right side of the editor.

codeCopy: This lesson demonstrates how to apply forces to particles. The key concept is that forces modify direction over time. We multiply the force (gravity) by delta time to ensure the effect is consistent regardless of frame rate. The formula is: newDirection = currentDirection + (force * deltaTime). This creates realistic physics-based movement where particles accelerate downward due to gravity.
objectives: Understand how UpdateDirectionBlock modifies particle velocity
Apply gravity force to particles using vector math
Use delta time for frame-rate independent physics
Combine forces with current direction to create acceleration
Understand the relationship between force, direction, and position

commonMistakes.mistake: Forgetting to multiply force by delta time
commonMistakes.explanation: Without delta time, physics will be frame-rate dependent. Particles will move faster on slower computers and slower on faster computers.
commonMistakes.solution: Always multiply forces by delta time: force * deltaTime. This ensures consistent behavior regardless of frame rate.

commonMistakes.mistake: Using position instead of direction for forces
commonMistakes.explanation: Forces modify direction (velocity), not position directly. Position is updated based on direction.
commonMistakes.solution: Apply forces to UpdateDirectionBlock, not UpdatePositionBlock. The chain should be: UpdateDirection → UpdatePosition.

commonMistakes.explanation: In most 3D coordinate systems, Y is up, so downward gravity should have a negative Y value.
commonMistakes.solution: Use negative Y for downward gravity: (0, -9.8, 0). Positive Y creates upward force.

homework: Try changing the gravity Y value to see how it affects particle fall speed
Create upward gravity by setting gravity Y to a positive value
Add horizontal forces by modifying gravity X or Z
Try combining multiple forces by adding more math operations
